children.name: to not tell sb sth they want to know
spill the beans
children.definition: to tell sb about sth that has been planned and was supposed to be a secret: lộ bí mật, tin tức

children.name: ‘Does Phillip know about our plan?’ ‘Yes, someone must have spilled the beans.’
examples: The class managed to keep the party a secret until Lorraine, unable to control herself any longer, spilled the beans.
I’m not going to give away how much I paid for it!

children.name: let slip
children.definition: to accidentally tell sb about sth: để lộ, “trượt chân”

children.name: let slip that
examples: He let slip that he was envious of his older brother.
Alex let slip that he had spoken to Julie on the phone and knew where she was.

children.name: let slip sth/let sth slip
examples: He inadvertently let slip the name of their new product.

children.name: give away
children.definition: give sth awayto tell people something secret, often without intending to: lộ bí mật
examples: The party was meant to be a surprise, but Sharon gave it away.
He was careful not to give away any trade secrets.

children.name: let the cat out of the bag
children.definition: to accidentally tell sb sth that allows them to guess a secret: lộ bí mật
examples: I’m sorry. Jim knows about last week’s party. I’m afraid I let the cat out of the bag.
Some idiot’s let the cat out of the bag -- Mrs Simpson realizes there’s something going on.

children.name: to tell sb in authority about sth wrong that sb has done
nark
children.definition: especially UK/narcespecially US  informal to secretly tell the police or sb in authority about sb else’s criminal activity, especially activities involving illegal drugs: chỉ điểm
examples: ‘How’d they get caught?’ ‘Somebody must’ve narked.’
nark on
If things get too risky, Ken’ll probably narc on you to the cops.

children.name: report
children.definition: to give information about a crime, an accident etc to the police or to sb in authority: báo cáo
examples: I’d like to report a theft.

children.name: report sb/sth missing/injured/killed
examples: The plane was reported missing.

children.name: report sth to sb
examples: All accidents must be reported at once to the aviation authority.
Many rape victims are too scared to report the attack to the police.
All accidents must be reported to the safety officer.

children.name: report sb (for sth)
examples: A man has been reported for a number of alleged motoring offences.
My neighbours reported me to the police for firing my rifle in the garden.

children.name: inform on
children.definition: /against sb to secretly tell the police that sb you know has done sth illegal: khai báo (tội phạm)
examples: Charlotte informed on her brother, who was then arrested for drug-dealing.
He categorically denied that he had ever informed on dissidents.
He denied that he had ever informed on his neighbours.

children.name: grass
children.definition: UK/squealUS  informal to tell thepolicewho is responsible for a crime or illegal activity when this seems disloyal: ném đá giấu tay, phỏng tay trên
examples: When we got there the cops were waiting for us. Somebody must have squealed.

children.name: grass on sb
examples: If the others ever found out he’d squealed on them, they’d kill him.
You grassed on us to save your own life.

children.name: grass sb up
examples: I don’t trust her -- what if she grasses us up?

children.name: blow the whistle
children.definition: to let people know about an illegal activity which has been happening for a long time, especially when you have been helping to keep it secret: “thổi còi”
examples: He was shot because he knew too much and was about to blow the whistle.

children.name: blow the whistle about
examples: It was the factory manager who eventually blew the whistle about the pollution scandal.

children.name: blow the whistle on
examples: We’d better get her before she has a chance to blow the whistle on us.

children.name: talk
children.definition: to give the police information about a crime that you know about or are involved in, especially when they are questioning you officially about it: khai
examples: The suspect was questioned for two hours, but refused to talk.
He said he’d come back and kill me if I talked.

children.name: refuse to talk
examples: Even under torture, Maskellrefused to talk.

children.name: tell tales
children.definition: UK /tattle (on sb)US  disapproving if a child tells tales or tattles on sb, they tell a parent or teacher about sth another child has done in order to cause trouble: méc lẻo

children.name: ‘Mum, Daniel’s broken a plate.’ ‘Don’t tell tales, dear.’
examples: Sarah’s teacher told her it was silly to keep tattling on her classmates.
You’ll lose all your friends if you keep tattling.

children.name: name names
children.definition: to tell sb in authority the names of people involved in a secret or illegal activity: tiết lộ tên
examples: If you don’t give me the money, I’m going to start naming names.
Someone -- I won’t name names -- has been caught stealing from the stores.

children.name: rat on
children.definition: sb/ split on sbUK informal  to tell sb in authority about sth wrong that sb has done, especially when this seems disloyal: phản bội
examples: Can you believe he ratted on his own brother?
Don’t worry, Robert’s reliable. He won’t split on us.

children.name: tell
children.definition: to tell sb in authority, especially a parent or teacher, about sthg wrong that sb has done - used by children: méc, mách
examples: I’m going to tell if you don’t stop messing around.

children.name: to tell sb sth that was a secret
tell
children.definition: to tell sb sth that should be kept secret:
examples: What did she say? Tell me!
If someone asked me to keep a secret I would never tell.

children.name: tell sb where/what/who etc
examples: He didn’t tell me where he got this information.

children.name: tell sb about sth
examples: Don’t tell anyone about this just yet.

children.name: tell sb a secret
examples: Come here Eva - let me tell you a secret.

children.name: tell sb sth in the strictest confidencetell sb sth on the condition that they do not tell anyone : với điều kiện là không nói cho ai biết
examples: I’m telling you this in the strictest confidence, so not a word to anyone.

children.name: reveal
children.definition: especially written to let people know about something that was previously kept secret:
examples: a test that can reveal a teacher’s hidden skills
revealsecrets
He may be prosecuted for revealing secrets about the security agency.
He was jailed for revealingsecretsto the Russians.
reveal (that)
He revealed that he had been in prison twice before.
reveal yourself (as/to be sth)
The violinist revealed himself as a talented interpreter of classical music.
revelation
1[C] a surprising fact about someone or something that was previously secret and is now made known : tiết lộ
revelation about/concerning
He resigned after revelations about his affair.
startling revelationsabout his background
revelation that
His wife divorced him after the revelationthathe was having an affair.
revelation that
revelations that two senior officers had lied in court
2[U] the act of suddenly making known a surprising fact that had previously been secret : tiết lộ
revelation of
the revelation of previously unknown facts

children.name: disclose
children.definition: to publicly reveal something such as a fact or a name that has been kept secret or hidden: vạch trần, phơi bày
examples: disclosure[C or U]
Investors were shocked by the disclosure when it was disclosed that the company director had been spending millions on luxury yachts and villas.

children.name: The agent does not have to disclose the amount his client paid.d
examples: Herefused to disclosethe identity of the politician.

children.name: disclose that
examples: It was disclosed that £3.5 million was needed to modernize the building.
In the report it was disclosed that neither pilot nor controller had any experience of the radar system in use at the time of the crash.

children.name: disclose information/details/evidence etc
examples: Some companies have already voluntarilydisclosedsimilarinformation.
The Security Service is unlikely to disclose any information.

children.name: disclose sb’s identitysay who sb is
examples: He refused to disclose the identity of the politician.

children.name: make sth public
children.definition: to make a piece of important information known to the public, especially after keeping it secret for some time: công bố, tiết lộ cho công chúng
examples: The Senator will make his decision public on Friday.
Reporters learned the news on Friday but agreed not to make it public until the following day.

children.name: make it public that
examples: Freddie Mercury died only two days after making it public that he was suffering from AIDS.

children.name: divulge
children.definition: to give sb some very important and often personal information which was previously secret or unknown: tiết lộ
examples: The other three companies refused to divulge their plans.

children.name: divulge what/where/when etc
examples: I’m afraid I cannot divulge what Jameson said to me.

children.name: divulge something to somebody
examples: The contract forbids employees to divulge details of this work to anyone outside the company.

children.name: expose
children.definition: to tell the public about the secret activities of a person or organization, because you think that people ought to know about sth morally wrong that is being done: phơi bày, bóc trẩn
examples: Her criminal activities were finally exposed in the Washington Post by political columnist Richard McCallum.
The film exposes the utter horror of war.
The reportexposestheweaknessesof modern medical practice.
The review exposed widespreadcorruptionin the police force.

children.name: expose sb as sth
examples: The baron was exposed as a liar and a cheat.

children.name: expose to
examples: They threatened to expose him to the media unless he changed his ways.

children.name: leak
children.definition: to deliberately give secret information to a newspaper, television company etc, when a government or other organization wants to keep it secret: rò rỉ
examples: The report’s findings had been leaked.
A man was charged today with leaking official secrets.
The Congressman was furious that the report had been leaked.
leak sth to sb
civil servants who leak information to the press
The contents of the fax were leaked to the press
He leaked the namestothe press.
It became evident from the leaks that something important was going on.
There have been severalsecurityleaks recently.
They traced the leak to a secretary in the finance department.

children.name: leak[
examples: C] a situation in which secret information is deliberately given to a newspaper, television company etc :

children.name: let sb in on
children.definition: to tell sb about a secret plan or idea so that they are involved in it, especially because you trust them:
examples: We’ll let you in on our plan if you promise to keep it a secret.
I know you’re up to something so you might as well let me in on it.
let sb in on a secretto allow someone to know something that you have not told anyone else:
Shall I let you in on a little secret?

children.name: blab
children.definition: to tell someone something that should be kept secret - use this when you disapprove of this: ba hoa, xoét miệng
examples: OK I’ll tell you, but you’d better not blab!

children.name: blab about
examples: She went and blabbed about Ernie’s surprise party.

children.name: blab to
examples: Better not say anything about it to Mickey -- he’ll just end up blabbing to someone.
Don’t go blabbing to your friends about this.

children.name: break
children.definition: if you break unpleasant news to sb, you tell it to them:
examples: I didn’t know how I was going tobreakthenewsto my mother.
It was the local newspaper which first broke thestory(= told the public) .
The doctor finally broke it to me that there was no cure.

children.name: break
children.definition: if news about an important event breaks, it becomes known:
examples: When thescandalbroke (= came to the public's attention) , the company director committed suicide.
News of his resignation broke yesterday.
The minister has refused to give any interviews since the scandal broke.

children.name: come out
children.definition: if sth that people knew nothing about comes out, people find out about it, especially as a result of an official inquiry: được phơi bày
examples: The truth about the scandal came out long after he had left office.
A few new facts came out at the trial.

children.name: it comes out that
examples: During the hearing it came out that she had tried to commit suicide.

children.name: come to light
children.definition: / be brought to light if new information or a new fact comes to light or is brought to light, people find out about it: được đưa ra ánh sáng
examples: Fresh evidence has come to light since the report was published.
Some serious problems have been brought to light by the latest report on health and safety.

children.name: it comes to light that/ it is brought to light that
examples: It came to light that the CIA knew he was a security risk.

children.name: emerge
children.definition: if facts emerge from a meeting or an inquiry, people find out about them: lộ ra
examples: More details of the plan emerged at yesterday’s meeting.
The facts behind the scandal are sure to emerge eventually.
She's the most exciting British singer to emerge on the pop scene for a decade.

children.name: it emerges that
examples: During the court case it emerged that both men had convictions for terrorist offences.
Ithas emergedthatsecret talks had been going on between the two companies before the takeover was announced.

children.name: get out
children.definition: if a piece of information gets out, people find out about it even though other people have tried very hard to keep it secret: lộ ra
examples: If any of this gets out, we’ll be in serious trouble.

children.name: word/ news etc gets out
examples: If word gets out that Jordan is here, we’ll be mobbed.

children.name: it gets out that
examples: If it gets out that we knew about this, we’ll lose all our clients.

children.name: it transpires that
children.definition: if it transpires that sth is true, people find out that it is true: lộ ra
examples: It now transpires that the prime minister knew about the deal all along.

children.name: leak out
children.definition: if secret information leaks out, a lot of people find out about it:
examples: No sooner had the news leaked out than my telephone started ringing.
News of the pay cuts had somehow leaked out .
